column4: Quick question, how do I chroot properly into my drive to run commands for the drive?
you've got the partition mounted, yes?
not yet, I remember something about mounting and looping it
no looping necessary; I assume you're in another OS or on a live cd?
okay. what partitions do you have? just one, mounted at / ?
Technically its not ubuntu, but Back|Track, but its a debian-type distro, so its close enough.
I can chroot in, I just thought I needed to loop some dir
oh, do you mean /proc and /dev and all that?
gotcha. go ahead and mount your root partition, say at /mnt/ubuntu
then you'll    sudo mount -t proc none /mnt/ubuntu/proc    and     sudo mount -o bind /dev /mnt/ubuntu/dev
once that's done, you can chroot:     sudo chroot /mnt/ubuntu /bin/bash      and     source /etc/profile     (that last command is inside the chroot)
